As a long-time Final Fantasy fan, I went into Final Fantasy 7: Ever Crisis with cautious optimism, hoping for a nostalgic yet engaging experience. Unfortunately, what I found instead was one of the most blatant “pay to win” titles I’ve ever played, wrapped in a convoluted system that feels designed to frustrate rather than entertain.

First and foremost, there’s barely any gameplay to speak of. Most missions are short, shallow encounters with minimal strategy required, leaving the whole experience feeling more like a series of automated cutscenes than an actual RPG. Worse, the storyline is practically impossible to follow, since missions constantly jump around the timeline without explanation. Anyone coming in for a cohesive retelling of the Final Fantasy 7 saga will walk away confused and disappointed.

The constant stream of “rewards” is another glaring problem. Instead of feeling satisfying, they come across like the psychological bait of a slot machine. Everything in the game, from unlocking equipment to powering up characters, is tied to gacha pulls and random drops, creating the atmosphere of a gambling addict’s dream rather than a true RPG progression system.

Speaking of progression, the user interface is a nightmare. Overly complicated menus and poorly explained mechanics make it nearly impossible to engage with equipment upgrades in any meaningful way. Half the time you’re left wondering what you’re supposed to be doing, unless of course, you’re willing to spend money.

And that’s really the heart of it: this game is a cash grab through and through. You’re constantly encouraged (and in some cases practically forced) to purchase premium currency just to progress. There’s little explanation for how one is supposed to advance without spending money, leaving free-to-play players completely out of the loop.

In the end, Final Fantasy 7: Ever Crisis is a shallow, confusing, pay-to-win mess that relies on nostalgia and the Final Fantasy brand name to lure players into its monetization trap. For fans hoping to relive the magic of Final Fantasy 7, this isn’t it, it’s just another gacha treadmill dressed in familiar clothing.

Verdict: 2/10 – A hollow experience, more interested in your wallet than your enjoyment.

Final Fantasy VII: Ever Crisis is initally addictive but quickly becomes painful.

Pros:
- Nostalgic presentation: Faithfully revisits the Final Fantasy VII universe with updated visuals and familiar characters.
- Strong visuals: Polished character models and cinematic cutscenes capture the spirit of the original.
- Decent music: Classic FF7 themes and sound design are recreated beautifully.
- Ambitious scope: Combines multiple FF7 titles (Crisis Core, Before Crisis, The First SOLDIER, etc.) into one overarching mobile package. On a side-note, I notice Steam sells a similar version of the game for a "pay once" price tag and without the pay2win aspects.
- Occasional free rewards: Early progression gives some free summons and weapons to get started.

Cons
- Excessive load screens: Constant loading between menus, missions, and even basic actions — all slow and disruptive to gameplay.
- Clunky interface: Too many taps and nested menus for simple tasks like upgrading or equipping gear. Areas like skill trees should have an "upgrade all" fucntion but somehow miss this feature turning a tree upgrade into a very long sequence of mouse moves and clicks.
- Severe Pay-to-Win mechanics: Many powerful weapons, outfits, and upgrades locked behind premium currency or gacha draws.
- Grinding or paying required: Sharp power spikes force players to either grind excessively or spend money to progress.
- Slow story-line pacing: Content is drip-fed; story missions are brief and often gated behind resource requirements.
- Repetitive game-play: Battle structure becomes monotonous, emphasising auto-combat and farming.
- Performance issues: Lag, long downloads, and memory bloat.

Verdict
Final Fantasy VII: Ever Crisis looks and sounds like a love letter to fans, but plays like a sluggish, monetisation driven grind. Its nostalgic charm and impressive visuals can’t make up for the constant loading screens, painfully slow pacing, and aggressive Pay-to-Win systems.

Unless you’re a die-hard FF7 fan willing to tolerate frustration for the sake of nostalgia, this one’s hard to recommend.

Score: 5/10 (for fans - give it a try) or 3/10 (for everyone else - avoid as it's a waste of time)

As a long-time Final Fantasy fan, I went into Final Fantasy 7: Ever Crisis with cautious optimism, hoping for a nostalgic yet engaging experience. Unfortunately, what I found instead was one of the most blatant “pay to win” titles I’ve ever played, wrapped in a convoluted system that feels designed to frustrate rather than entertain.

First and foremost, there’s barely any gameplay to speak of. Most missions are short, shallow encounters with minimal strategy required, leaving the whole experience feeling more like a series of automated cutscenes than an actual RPG. Worse, the storyline is practically impossible to follow, since missions constantly jump around the timeline without explanation. Anyone coming in for a cohesive retelling of the Final Fantasy 7 saga will walk away confused and disappointed.

The constant stream of “rewards” is another glaring problem. Instead of feeling satisfying, they come across like the psychological bait of a slot machine. Everything in the game, from unlocking equipment to powering up characters, is tied to gacha pulls and random drops, creating the atmosphere of a gambling addict’s dream rather than a true RPG progression system.

Speaking of progression, the user interface is a nightmare. Overly complicated menus and poorly explained mechanics make it nearly impossible to engage with equipment upgrades in any meaningful way. Half the time you’re left wondering what you’re supposed to be doing, unless of course, you’re willing to spend money.

And that’s really the heart of it: this game is a cash grab through and through. You’re constantly encouraged (and in some cases practically forced) to purchase premium currency just to progress. There’s little explanation for how one is supposed to advance without spending money, leaving free-to-play players completely out of the loop.

In the end, Final Fantasy 7: Ever Crisis is a shallow, confusing, pay-to-win mess that relies on nostalgia and the Final Fantasy brand name to lure players into its monetization trap. For fans hoping to relive the magic of Final Fantasy 7, this isn’t it, it’s just another gacha treadmill dressed in familiar clothing.

Verdict: 2/10 – A hollow experience, more interested in your wallet than your enjoyment.
